<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 133, 636, 158]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 183, 193, 213]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 233, 175, 263]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 183, 905, 272]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 288, 178, 304]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 288, 905, 304]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 376, 329]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 312, 905, 329]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 338, 905, 353]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 365, 393, 381]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 359, 410]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 222, 445]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 808, 570]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 213, 614]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 615, 729, 648]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 85, 128, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>Data</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 116, 574, 134]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 148, 621, 166]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 180, 606, 198]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 212, 606, 230]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 243, 606, 261]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 274, 606, 292]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 305, 628, 323]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 336, 608, 354]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 368, 636, 386]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{ J K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 399, 670, 417]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2 \text{ kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 430, 630, 448]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{ F m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 448, 630, 477]]<|/det|>
\[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 490, 616, 508]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 522, 668, 540]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{ W m}^{-2} \text{ K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 580, 170, 597]]<|/det|>
<form>Formulae</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 615, 562, 632]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[438, 631, 562, 650]]<|/det|>
\[\nu^2 = u^2 + 2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 664, 532, 682]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 695, 524, 712]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F = \rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 733, 536, 761]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_0 = \frac{f_s V}{V \pm V_s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 777, 532, 794]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I = A n v q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 808, 590, 826]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 839, 601, 867]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 92, 539, 111]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential \(\phi = - \frac{GM}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 133, 554, 153]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{P}} = - \frac{GMm}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 176, 571, 196]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas \(p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 214, 539, 231]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion \(a = - \omega^2 x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 245, 567, 262]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m. \(\nu = \nu_0 \cos \omega t\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 262, 615, 288]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - \chi^2)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 304, 544, 325]]<|/det|>
electric potential \(V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 348, 544, 375]]<|/det|>
electrical potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{P}} = \frac{Qq}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 395, 601, 425]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series \(\frac{1}{C} = \frac{1}{C_1} + \frac{1}{C_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 440, 598, 459]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel \(C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 475, 559, 497]]<|/det|>
discharge of a capacitor \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 520, 524, 546]]<|/det|>
Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{nq}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 560, 561, 577]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage \(x = x_0 \sin \omega t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 592, 544, 608]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 625, 544, 653]]<|/det|>
decay constant \(\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 680, 576, 714]]<|/det|>
intensity reflection coefficient \(\frac{I_{\mathrm{R}}}{I_0} = \frac{(Z_1 - Z_2)^2}{(Z_1 + Z_2)^2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 730, 556, 747]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann law \(L = 4\pi \sigma r^2 T^4\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 768, 556, 794]]<|/det|>
Doppler redshift \(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} \approx \frac{\Delta f}{f} \approx \frac{\nu}{c}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 220, 920, 256]]<|/det|>
Two cylinders X and Y each contain a sample of an ideal gas. The samples are in thermal equilibrium with each other.

X has a volume of \(0.0260 \text{m}^3\) and contains \(0.740 \text{mol}\) of gas at a pressure of \(1.20 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). Y has a volume of \(0.0430 \text{m}^3\) and contains gas at a pressure of \(2.90 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). Data for the two cylinders are shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 205, 918, 241]]<|/det|>
Two isolated charged metal spheres X and Y are near to each other in a vacuum. The centres of the spheres are \(1.2 \text{m}\) apart, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
A proton is held at rest on the line joining the centres of the spheres in **(b)** at the position where \(x = 0.60 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 349, 395]]<|/det|>
The proton is released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 146, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors X and Y are connected in series to a power supply of voltage \(V,\) as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 125, 707, 269]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 281, 534, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 640, 332]]<|/det|>
The capacitance of X is \(C_{\mathrm{X}}\) and the capacitance of Y is \(C_{\mathrm{Y}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 344, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
Derive an expression, in terms of \(C_{\mathrm{X}}\) and \(C_{\mathrm{Y}}\), for the combined capacitance \(C_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the capacitors in this circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 353, 394]]<|/det|>
Explain your reasoning.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 611, 146, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 821, 630]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors P and Q are connected in parallel to a power supply of voltage \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
The capacitance of P is \(200 \mu \text{F}\). The capacitance \(C_{\text{Q}}\) of Q can be varied between 0 and \(400 \mu \text{F}\). When \(C_{\text{Q}} = 0\), the total energy stored in the capacitors is \(2.5 \text{mJ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 672, 181, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 672, 520, 691]]<|/det|>
Show that the supply voltage \(V\) is 5.0 V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 812, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 82, 180, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 81, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total energy, in mJ, stored in the capacitors when \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\) has its maximum value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 284, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<form>total energy = .................................................... mJ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 316, 180, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 314, 920, 350]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 6.2, sketch the variation of the total energy \(E\) stored in the capacitors with \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\), as \(C_{\mathrm{Q}}\) varies from 0 to 400 \(\mu \mathrm{F}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 357, 744, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 700, 534, 719]]<|/det|>
<mark>Fig. 6.2</mark>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 718, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 747, 920, 766]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 81, 562, 101]]<|/det|>
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 922, 133]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 160, 922, 185]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 205, 146, 224]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 205, 905, 225]]<|/det|>
Fig. 7.1 shows a coil at rest in a uniform magnetic field that is parallel to the axis of the coil.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 234, 757, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 424, 554, 443]]<|/det|>
The coil is connected to a centre-zero voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 863, 473]]<|/det|>
The flux density \(B\) of the uniform magnetic field varies with time \(t\) as shown in Fig. 7.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 483, 833, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 682, 534, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 712, 761, 732]]<|/det|>
The coil consists of 340 turns, each of cross-sectional area \(3.2 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 744, 180, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 744, 737, 763]]<|/det|>
Calculate the maximum magnetic flux through one turn of the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 902, 920, 921]]<|/det|>
<form>maximum magnetic flux = .................................................... $Wb$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 902, 920, 921]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 82, 175, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 81, 811, 101]]<|/det|>
Determine the maximum rate of change of magnetic flux linkage in the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 221, 920, 241]]<|/det|>
maximum rate of change of flux linkage = ......................................... Wbs\(^{- 1}\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 253, 180, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 252, 808, 272]]<|/det|>
State the maximum electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(V_0\) induced across the coil.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 297, 920, 318]]<|/det|>
\[V_0 = .................................................... V \ [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 330, 180, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 7.3, sketch the variation of the e.m.f. \(V\) induced across the coil with \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 6.0 \text{ms}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 373, 816, 530]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 549, 534, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 566, 920, 585]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 597, 180, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 562, 616]]<|/det|>
The variation of \(V\) with \(t\) can be described by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 628, 556, 645]]<|/det|>
\[V = A\sin Bt\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 658, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 689, 715, 707]]<|/det|>
Determine the values of \(A\) and \(B\). Give units with your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 800, 917, 820]]<|/det|>
<form>A = ............................................ unit .................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 833, 917, 851]]<|/det|>
<form>B = ............................................ unit .................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 848, 920, 867]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 878, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 14]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 273, 710, 294]]<|/det|>
The galaxy is moving away from the Earth at a speed of \(6.2 \times 10^{6} \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 146, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 305, 180, 324]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 305, 920, 341]]<|/det|>

<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 410, 920, 432]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 444, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 8.1, draw the three lines in possible positions in the spectrum seen by the observer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 148, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 490, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
The lines in Fig. 8.1 correspond to electron transitions down to the energy level \(-3.40 \text{eV}\). One of the lines represents emitted radiation of wavelength \(488 \text{nm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 181, 556]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 537, 601, 556]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 680, 920, 699]]<|/det|>
<form>photon energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 271, 920, 291]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 470, 920, 490]]<|/det|>

J [1]
